awd_titl_txt: Colorado-Wyoming Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (CO-WY LSAMP)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in their efforts to significantly increase the numbers of students matriculating into and successfully completing high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines in order to diversify the STEM workforce. Particular emphasis is placed on transforming undergraduate STEM education through innovative, evidence-based recruitment and retention strategies, and relevant educational experiences in support of racial and ethnic groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. These strategies facilitate the production of well-prepared students highly-qualified and motivated to pursue graduate education or careers in STEM.

For the United States (U.S.) to remain globally competitive, it is vital that it taps into the talent of all its citizens and provides exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy. The Colorado LSAMP (CO-AMP), which began in 1995, is expanding its alliance to include two new partners in Wyoming to become the Colorado-Wyoming Alliance for Minority Participation (CO-WY AMP). This consortium of sixteen institutions is a unique reconstituted alliance with an urban/rural dichotomy, encompassing a distance of 550 miles between two states.  CO-WY AMP will continue to work tirelessly to increase the representation of underrepresented students in the Western U.S. by preparing them to excel in an economically competitive global workforce. 

CO-WY AMP will use Engagement, Capacity and Continuity: A Trilogy for Student Success (ECC Trilogy) as a model to advance students in the sciences and quantitative disciplines on all partner campuses, which include two research-intensive universities, five high research universities, three comprehensive universities, one liberal arts college, and five community colleges. The three factors of the ECC Trilogy are defined as: engaging the student both academically and socially to foster positive attitudes and increase subject mastery (Engagement); preparing the student for fundamental knowledge necessary to advance (Capacity); and providing access that offers resources necessary for advancement (Continuity). CO-WY AMP will apply the trilogy model through the following goals: 
1)	Increase retention and subsequent attainment of baccalaureate degrees;
2)	Increase the quality and quantity of students transferring from 2-year to 4-year institutions by providing skill-building interventions to strengthen students' mathematical knowledge and Summer Bridge experiences to enrich STEM achievement;
3)	Facilitate pure and applied undergraduate research experiences both domestic and international and develop summer research experiences at both 2 and 4-year institutions; and
4)	Expand capacity for preparation and matriculation into graduate programs.

The knowledge generating research study, namely "the Mathematics Research Study", seeks to understand ultimately whether the algebra skills of community college students could be improved using cognitively-guided and self-reflective supplemental materials outside of the classroom environment. The materials will be developed collaboratively by community college algebra instructors, a mathematics education specialist, and a cognitive specialist.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Louis Stokes Colorado-Wyoming Alliance for Minority Participation (LS CO-WY AMP), established as the Colorado-AMP in 1995, is a consortium of sixteen institutions of higher education. The addition of Wyoming in 2015 increased CO-AMP's outreach to American Indian students on the Wind River Indian Reservation. Since its inception, CO-WY has built an infrastructure for collaboration, integration, enhancement, and initiation of state-of-the-art programs to enroll, retain, and graduate URM students in STEM. As part of the consortium goals, CO-WY has also continued its mission to assure continuation and institutionalization of best practice programming while enhancing existing programs, integrating URM STEM students into a campus community through bridge programs, early research projects, and international field experiences. 

In the LS CO-WY AMP network, the total number of URM STEM B.S. graduates at participating institutions increased by 81%, from 999 at baseline (2015-16) to 1,810 (2019-2020). Over the last five-year phase of funding, the number of URM students enrolled in STEM programs at partner institutions rose from 8,377 in 2015-16 to 10,664 in 2019-20 (27% increase). LS CO-WY AMP has also impacted participants to make profound changes in their academic careers and lives, with an extensive history of expanding participation at partner sites and a record of significant achievements. 

During the last award, LS CO-WY AMP emphasized undergraduate research, both domestic and international, which is considered a high-impact practice that increases students' likelihood of completing their degrees. For many URM students, devoting extra time outside of class for lab research isn't economically feasible, as economic pressures often dictate that the student entirely finance or partially supplement their education. To combat this challenge, LS CO-WY AMP increased its emphasis on the expansion of research experiences where students were provided room and board, as well as a stipend to defray costs. The evidence is very clear that to reduce attrition rates and assist students in developing a scientific identity, early involvement in research is key to a higher probability of URM students remaining in their major and graduating in STEM. International field/laboratory projects also broaden the perception of what a STEM degree can do for URM students. URM students often leave the sciences if they cannot see a direct relationship between their community and what they're doing in school. International projects help remedy this disconnect by providing students an opportunity to put their engineering/scientific skills to work in their country/region of heritage while facilitating the development and implementation of sustainable community projects. One hundred sixty-four students participated in domestic and international research in the award period. 

Part of the Senior Alliance research responsibility and mission, LS CO-WY AMP has collected data on math performance in URM students at its partner community colleges. As a by-product of this effort, LS CO-WY AMP wrote the Mathematics Study, a research study to test whether we can improve the success of community college algebra students by using cognitively-guided and self-reflective supplemental materials outside the classroom. A survey was conducted to provide insight into what community college math instructors understood about the science of learning materials as it applies to mathematics pedagogy. Results were then used to inform core goals of the project: update information on mathematical pedagogy, ways to increase constructive discourse in the community college classroom and provide skill-building interventions to strengthen students' mathematical knowledge, which can increase the quality and quantity of students transferring from 2-year to 4-year institutions.

Because algebra textbooks are not designed to use interleaving and spacing strategies, resulting in students' math education being discretized and categorized into separate topics that do not naturally build on previous topics, it was proposed that supplemental materials be developed to provide informative feedback to instructors about what students understood and what they had difficulty understanding. Three sets of supplemental mathematics materials were designed. The project was innovative as it combined three important elements that can be used to enhance student learning: guided instruction, self-reflection, and metacognition. Results of the Math Study, in combination with prior research, suggest that community college students have extremely limited study time due to family and work obligations, yet instructors may underappreciate the degree to which these external commitments affect how much students can study. Therefore, it may be useful for professional development to help community college instructors shift their emphasis on the amount of studying or effort to a focus on quality of studying. A proactive, early intervention to teach effective study skills and learning strategies would likely move the classroom towards a mastery orientation, build student confidence, improve self-efficacy and persistence, and lead to higher learning and achievement. As a direct outcome of a LS CO-WY AMP's conveyance of results from the Math study, a paper titled 'Community College Instructors' Perceptions of Success in Mathematics, has been published and appears in MathAMATYC Educator.


Last Modified: 12/19/2022
Modified by: Ernest L Chavez
por.por_txt_cntn:
